In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Philippine Department of Energy (DOE) requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to provide policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) to assist the government of the 
Philippines in managing consumer protection as the power sector moves toward open access1 
and electricity retail market competition.2 This is part of the government’s ongoing reform of the 
power sector that began in 2001, when the Electric Power Industry Reform Act (EPIRA) was 
approved. With the impending shift to open access, measures are needed to ensure consumer 
benefit and the effective regulation of the sector. Agreement was reached with officials in the 
DOE on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, cost estimates, and terms of reference.3 The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Nine years after EPIRA passage, several objectives of the act have been achieved such 
as the unbundling of rates, removal of subsidies, and privatization of the transmission network 
through  a  management  concession  agreement  with  the  National  Grid  Corporation  of  the 
Philippines. Wholesale electricity spot market operations since 2006 have resulted in wholesale 
competition in generation, the privatization of 91.8% of generation assets of the National Power 
Corporation as of April 2010, and the regulation of transmission and distribution by the Energy 
Regulatory Commission (ERC) since 2001. But much remains to be done to achieve the power 
sector reform objective of ensuring the sustainable supply of electricity at reasonable cost.   
 
3.  Open access and retail competition would complete the institution of competition through 
the entire cycle from generation to distribution. Only by implementing them can competitive 
pressure on power-generating companies be realized, bringing efficiency to the sector and 
ultimately reducing prices, the ultimate goal for consumers. 
 
4.  The government is set to implement open access, the next phase of reform of the 
Philippine power sector, by October 2012.4 This will introduce a new dimension to the Philippine 
electricity market, allowing consumers to select their electricity supplier. International experience 
shows that, with open access and consumers’ general lack of understanding of reform issues, 
consumer complaints are likely to increase, which will further burden the ERC, which handles 
consumer complaints in addition to regulating the industry.  
 
5.  The ERC was established to promote and protect long-term consumer interests in terms 
of the quality, reliability, and pricing of sustainable electricity supply by overseeing network 
investment, retail reforms, and effective competition. Although significant reforms have been 
implemented since 2001, the sector still has high electricity prices and other problems, with 
consumers absorbing the burden of high rates. Consumers have not yet benefited from reform 
in terms of lower electricity prices.5  The main competitive element—open access—has not yet 
been implemented. 
                                                
1  Open access means that the utility’s wires are open and can be used by consumers and generators to buy and sell 
electricity from alternative sources, with payment to the utility of regulated transmission and distribution charges. 
2  Retail competition enables a customer to shop around for a cheaper source of electricity, switch directly to the 
cheaper alternative, and pay to the utility regulated transmission and distribution charges.  
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB website on 18 November 2011. 
4  Customers with an average monthly peak demand 1 MW in the 12 months preceding 26 December 2011 can 
choose their electricity suppliers; Open Access will be gradually introduced to customers with lower consumption 
thresholds.   
5  ADB. 2009. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors:  Proposed Loan and 
Administration of Grant to the Republic of the Philippines for the  Philippine Energy Efficiency Project. Manila.

2 
 
6.   The shift to open access should be accompanied by measures to ensure consumer 
protection. EPIRA’s objectives clearly include consumer protection, as does the ERC’s mission. 
With  open  access,  consumers  will  need  ready  access  to  information  on  tariffs,  clear 
understanding of the operation of the wholesale market, and any changes that may be proposed 
to  market  rules.  In  addition,  consumers  need  to  understand  the  market  structure,  the 
competitive forces that may drive price volatility. With the broad understanding of the market 
dynamics, a contestable customer—customers who has right to shop for a supplier under the 
Open Access regime—will be able to decide on the price and quality of service package suitable 
to that customer’s need.  
 
7.  As gains from power sector reforms are measured in terms of consumer benefits, it is 
essential  to  ensure  that  competition  and  operational  efficiencies  translate  into  high-quality 
electricity supply at reasonable rates. Consumers should be protected from imperfections in the 
electricity industry and market. Consumer protection in the current system is under the ERC. The 
current mechanism for handling consumer complaints in the electricity industry is inadequate.6 
In a deregulated environment that offers consumers more choices, the role of an ombudsman or 
an appointed official to receive and investigate complaints from individuals against electricity 
companies will be critical. Consumers’ rights and obligations need to be clearly defined for 
prompt and effective dispute resolution. The staff responsible for receiving and investigating 
complaints must understand the rights and obligations of consumers in a deregulated industry 
and have the skills to resolve conflicts fairly. The ERC agrees with this view and will support 
establishing an ombudsman in the energy sector. 
 
8.  Consumer  protection  is  an  energy  policy  priority  of  the  government,  which  has 
undertaken initiatives like improving energy self-sufficiency using cheaper indigenous energy 
resources to reduce dependence on imported oil, while avoiding increased generation cost. 
Enabling customers to choose electricity suppliers will make the power sector more efficient.  
 
9.  In  parallel  with  government  strategies,  ADB’s  current  country  partnership  strategy 
supports  medium-term  policy  reforms  pertaining  to  power  distribution.7 It  has  consistently 
supported the government’s restructuring of the power sector, which started with the approval of 
the $300 million Power Sector Restructuring Program on 16 December 1998.8 In December 
2002, ADB supplemented this loan with a partial credit guarantee to help finance additional 
adjustment  costs  associated  with  restructuring.9 Further,  the  Power  Sector  Development 
Program was approved in December 2006.10 ADB has provided technical assistance grants to 
the energy sector on tariff and pricing studies, regulation, and consumer impact assessment to 
support reform since 2001.     
 
 
                                                
6  ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance to Republic of the the Philippines for a Competition Policy for the Electricity 
Sector. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2009. Country Operations Business Plan: Philippines, 2010–2012. Manila. 
8  ADB. 1998. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Technical

9  ADB. 2002. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Partial Credit

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  This TA is part of a sustained effort by ADB to assist the government in its continuing 
restructuring of the power sector. The outcome will be to make consumers aware of open 
access, electricity competition issues, and their rights and opportunities in the new electricity 
market. The impact will be an effective and efficient electricity market. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
11.  The TA will be implemented through wide-range consultation with the government, the 
electricity industry, and consumers and the adoption of international best practices. It will have 
three components: (i) stakeholder capacity building, (ii) establishing a consumer consultation 
group, and (iii) establishing a dispute-resolution scheme for consumer complaints.  
 
  1.  Stakeholder Capacity Building  
   
12.  Open access is a new concept for electricity consumers. Market competition in electricity 
generation has existed for years but is still unknown to most consumers. Other features of 
power  reforms  such  as  green  energy  options  and  net  metering  that  would  directly  affect 
consumers will be implemented in the future. What these concepts are, how they work, their 
attributes, and how they affect prices are questions to which consumers should know the 
answers.  Consumers  should  be  empowered  by  information  and  knowledge  on  what  open 
access and electricity market competition provide. They should be made aware of their rights 
and opportunities under the new market set-up and apprised of developments in a timely way to 
instill confidence and enable interacting in a new market environment.  
 
13.  Likewise, the staff of government agencies in the energy sector, such as the DOE, ERC, 
Philippine Electricity Market Corporation (PEMC), and National Electrification Administration, 
should be prepared for the new market and its consequences for consumer protection. To equip 
government  agencies  regarding  the  requirements  of  consumer  protection  and  empowering 
consumers  in  a  new  market  arrangement,  this  TA  will  support  a  stakeholder  awareness 
campaign comprising (i) an interactive website where all information pertaining to electricity will 
be made available and consumers receive answers to their electricity-related questions; (ii) an 
advocacy  campaign  including  training,  seminars,  workshops,  and  consultations  bringing 
together  government  staff,  consumers,  electricity  industry  players,  and  nongovernment 
organizations; and (iii) a consumer survey to establish baseline data on consumers. 
 
  2.  Establishing a Consumer Consultation Group  
 
14.  Privatization and the introduction of competition accompanies the restructuring of the 
Philippine electric power industry from a vertically integrated monopoly into a market in which 
generation, transmission, and distribution come under separate companies and utilities, with the 
adoption of a wholesale electricity market and, eventually, open access to it. Privatization 
necessarily entails investment, and competition positions market players in ways that can adjust 
electricity prices.  
 
15.  The  ERC  regulates  electricity  transmission,  distribution,  and  retailing.  It  implements 
incentive-based regulation of power transmission and distribution, and there is open competition 
in generation, which is monitored and managed by the PEMC. While the ERC and the PEMC

4 
 
consult consumers on every decision, consumers have not exercised any reasonable influence 
on the decision making of these entities. This leaves the regulator unaware of the consumer 
perspective on many of the issues that affect them. This TA will support the formation of a 
consumer  consultative  group  of  members  representing  organizations  across  affected 
jurisdictions. The members will consult with their constituencies from time to time on electricity 
issues that affect them, and the group will inform the government on these issues, enabling the 
regulator to understand conditions for consumers and strike a balance between consumers and 
regulated entities.  
 
  3.  Dispute Resolution Scheme for Consumer Complaints  
 
16.  Power  sector  reforms  have  been  implemented  toward  providing  consumers  more 
choices on electricity use and provision. Open access, for instance, comes with a system that 
allows customers to change supplier after negotiating a contract with more favorable terms of 
price and service. From the choice of the supplier to electricity delivery, its use, and payment for 
it, the consumer deals with the electricity supplier and distribution utility. Problems with bills 
resulting from switching, or related to electricity supply, such as power cuts and connection 
problems, may arise between customers and these entities. To protect consumers and provide 
a venue for resolving these conflicts, this TA will propose setting up an energy ombudsman that 
will  receive  complaints,  investigate  them,  and  facilitate  their  resolution,  without  charge  to 
consumers.   
 
17.  The  government  considers  consumer  protection  a  priority.  Establishing  an  energy 
ombudsman  would  require  an  enabling  law  or  government  order  to  change  current 
arrangements,  under  which  consumer  protection  is  lodged  with  the  ERC.  Consumer 
empowerment should be accompanied by market monitoring to check whether consumers are 
benefiting from competition in the electricity market or falling prey to possible market distortions. 
Protection mechanisms should both cater to consumer complaints and, by their existence, 
shield consumers from market abuses.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and 
Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  in  the  amount  of  $500,000  and  administered  by  ADB.  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, transport, staff 
resources, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The DOE will be the executing agency, working in collaboration with the ERC, PEMC, 
National Electrification Administration, and other government agencies. The DOE will designate 
a project coordinator during contract negotiations and counterpart staff that will work closely with 
consultants during project implementation. ADB will, with the support of consultants, conduct 
workshops, training, seminars, and consultations with stakeholders. Disbursements under the 
TA will be in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time).  
 
20.  The project will be implemented over 24 months from May 2012 to  April 2014. Individual 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Any procurement made will be carried out in

5 
 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. The team of international consultants will 
include a consumer protection specialist and team leader (10 person-months) and an electricity 
market expert (5 person-months). The national consultants will be an advocacy specialist (7 
person-months) and a web developer (3 person-months). The consultant team will prepare an 
inception report within 4 weeks of the beginning of project implementation, an interim report at 5 
months, a draft final report at 19 months, and a final report at 24 months. The implementation of 
stakeholder capacity building will be part of the interim report, and establishing the consumer 
consultative group and the proposed design for a dispute-resolution scheme for consumer 
complaints will be included in the final report. The outline terms of reference for consultants are 
in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of  the  Philippines  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund for Consumer Protection in a Competitive Electricity Market with 
Open Access, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance (TA) will support the Department of 
Energy and Energy Regulatory Commission on consumer protection aspects of Philippine power 
sector reforms. It will help provide measures to address consumer concerns arising from power 
sector reform regarding electricity market competition, open access and how customers switch 
providers,  and  other  future  changes.  International  and  national  experts  will  be  engaged  as 
individual consultants to introduce international best practices and provide local expertise in (i) 
empowering electricity consumers and capacity building in the government, (ii) institutionalizing 
electricity  consumer  consultations,  and (iii)  establishing  a  protection mechanism for  electricity 
consumers. 
 
A.  Consumer Protection Specialist (international, 10 person-months) 
 
2.  As team leader, the specialist will manage TA implementation and be responsible for 
coordinating the inputs and outputs of all consultants in consultation with ADB and the Department 
of Energy. Specific tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Provide a framework for establishing a consumer protection mechanism for the 
Philippine  power  sector  that  includes  a  consumer  awareness  campaign  and 
establishing a consumer consultative group and an energy ombudsman. 
(ii)  Clearly establish the policy intent regarding consumer protection envisaged under 
the Electric Power Industry Reform Act.  
(iii)  Discuss  the  importance  of  electricity  market  competition  and  open  access  to 
achieving full sector reforms and how they link directly with consumers. Establish 
the need and benefits of consumer protection in a competitive market to policy 
makers with all stakeholders.  
(iv)  Review the current consumer protection mechanism in the power sector, as well as 
its framework, power, and functions and how much assistance it offers consumers. 
(v)  With the electricity market specialist, identify the hurdles to be overcome in drawing 
up and implementing a consumer protection mechanism in an electricity market with 
open access.  
(vi)   Study consumer protection in other jurisdictions and establish best practices  in 
support of the most vulnerable consumers. 
(vii)   Develop a paper for establishing an energy ombudsman, including the requirements 
for establishing an energy ombudsman; the structure, nature, power, and functions 
of the energy ombudsman office; interface with government and private entities; 
funding; market monitoring aspects; and the effects of decisions. 
(viii)  Study consumer consultative groups in other jurisdictions.  
(ix)  With the advocacy specialist, provide a mechanism for establishing and operating a 
consumer consultative group, taking into account how such groups operate in other 
jurisdictions; membership; functions; funding; and interface with the government, 
private entities, and the proposed energy ombudsman. 
(x)  With  the  electricity  market  specialist  and  advocacy  specialist,  conduct  training, 
seminars, workshops, and consultations with stakeholders such as the government, 
the electricity industry, consumers, and nongovernment organizations. 
 (xi)  Develop an electricity consumer charter.

10  Appendix 3 
B.  Electricity Market Specialist (international, 5 person-months) 
 
3.  The electricity market specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Provide  specialized  training  and  seminars  for  government  staff  on  the  current 
Philippine electricity market and industry, attributes of the competitive market such 
as open access and how consumers switch suppliers; green energy options; net 
metering;  regulation;  and  the  roles  of  the  different  electricity  entities  like  the 
Department of Energy, Power Sector Assets and Liabilities Management,  Philippine 
Electricity  Market  Corporation,  National  Electrification  Administration,  Energy 
Regulatory  Commission,  National  Grid  Corporation  of  the  Philippines,  and 
distribution utilities. 
(ii)  Identify examples of best practices in market reform. 
(iii)  Conduct a regulatory and policy analysis of the Philippine electricity market and 
industry. 
(iv)  Review the Philippine electricity market and industry and develop a structure and 
flow diagram indicating the functions and participation of the different entities and 
electricity players. 
(v)  Review  the  operation  of the  Philippine  electricity  market  and  risks  of abuse of 
market power. 
(vi)  Assist the team leader in identifying what consumer complaints the proposed energy 
ombudsman address. 
(vii)  Assist in conducting workshops and consultation with stakeholders. 
 
C.  Advocacy Specialist (national, 7 person-months) 
 
4.  The advocacy specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Develop a sustainable consumer awareness campaign plan that can include the 
proposed  consumer  consultative  group  continuing  to  conduct  information  and 
education communication campaign.  
(ii)  With the consumer protection specialist, conduct workshops and consultations with 
consumers, the electricity industry, and nongovernment organizations on consumer 
protection. 
(iii)  Lead the establishment and operation of the consumer consultative group. 
(iv)  With the consumer protection specialist, consult with various stakeholders on 
establishing and operating the consumer consultative group. 
(v)  Cause the actual operation of the consumer consultative group. 
(vi)  Survey consumers to establish baseline data on electricity consumers, identify 
electricity consumer concerns, and determine consumers’ understanding of the 
electricity market. 
 
D.  Web Developer (national, 3 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant will develop a website for consumers that 
  (i)    contains all information and data relating to electricity, market updates, consumer 
rights and opportunities including switching to alternative electricity retailers and 
potential savings, and processes for filing complaints; 
  (ii)    facilitates interaction between consumers and the website administrator; 
  (iii)    contains a system whereby data from mobile phones can be migrated into the 
website; and 
    (iv)  provides a platform for processing data gathered through surveys.
